SIZE([conf IN conflicts WHERE EXISTS { MATCH (conf)-[:IS_CLASSIFIED_AS_CONFLICT_TYPE]->(:ConflictType {type: "International Armed Conflict (IAC)"}) }]) AS total_IAC, [conf IN conflicts WHERE EXISTS { MATCH (conf)-[:IS_CLASSIFIED_AS_CONFLICT_TYPE]->(:ConflictType {type: "International Armed Conflict (IAC)"}) } | conf.name] AS IAC_conflict_names WITH country_name, total_conflicts, total_IAC, IAC_conflict_names, conflicts, all_actors, conflict_types, [conf IN conflicts | { conflict_name: COALESCE(conf.name, "Unknown"), conflict_classification: COALESCE([item IN conflict_types WHERE item.conflict = conf | item.type][0], "Unclassified"), conflict_overview: COALESCE(conf.overview, "No Overview Available"), applicable_ihl_law: COALESCE(conf.applicable_law, "Not Specified"), conflict_citation: COALESCE(conf.citation, "No Citation Available"), state_parties: CASE WHEN SIZE([p IN all_actors WHERE "StateActor" IN labels(p) AND (p)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]->(conf)]) = 0 THEN "No state actors recorded" ELSE apoc.text.join([p IN all_actors WHERE "StateActor" IN labels(p) AND (p)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]->(conf) | p.name], ", ") END, non_state_parties: CASE WHEN SIZE([p IN all_actors WHERE "NonStateActor" IN labels(p) AND (p)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]->(conf)]) = 0 THEN "No non-state actors recorded" ELSE apoc.text.join([p IN all_actors WHERE "NonStateActor" IN labels(p) AND (p)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]->(conf) | p.name], ", ") END }] AS conflict_details WITH country_name, total_conflicts, total_IAC, IAC_conflict_names, conflict_details, CASE WHEN total_conflicts = 0 THEN "According to RULAC, there are currently no recorded 'International Armed Conflict (IAC)' conflicts involving " + country_name + " as a state party." ELSE "According to RULAC, there are currently " + toString(total_conflicts) + " total distinct 'International Armed Conflict (IAC)' conflict(s) involving " + country_name + " as a party to conflict. Output:
According to the research data provided, China is a state party to the following international armed conflict:

### International Armed Conflict between India and China

This conflict involves India and China over the control of two main regions: Aksai Chin and Arunachal Pradesh, along with several smaller regions along the Sino-Indian border. Both countries are party to the four 1949 Geneva Conventions and are bound by customary international humanitarian law.

Category: 1b. Retrieve Conflict Data BY TYPE (name, classification, overview, applicable IHL, parties) for Conflict(s) Taking Place in a Specific Country or Region
Input: Which non-international armed conflicts are currently active in the Sahel region?
Generated Query: WITH ["011"] AS target_region_codes, "Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)" AS target_conflict_type MATCH (gr:GeoRegion) WHERE gr.UN_M49Code IN target_region_codes OPTIONAL MATCH (co:Country)-[:BELONGS_TO]->(gr) OPTIONAL MATCH (co)<-[:IS_TAKING_PLACE_IN_COUNTRY]-(c:Conflict)-[:IS_CLASSIFIED_AS_CONFLICT_TYPE]->(ct:ConflictType) WHERE ct.type = target_conflict_type OPTIONAL MATCH (c)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]-(actor) WITH COALESCE(gr.name, "Sahel") AS region_name, COALESCE(gr.UN_M49Code, target_region_codes[0]) AS geo_region_UN_M49Code, COALESCE(COLLECT(DISTINCT c), []) AS conflicts, COALESCE(COLLECT(DISTINCT actor), []) AS all_actors, target_conflict_type AS classification, COALESCE(COLLECT(DISTINCT co), []) AS countries WITH region_name, geo_region_UN_M49Code, conflicts, all_actors, classification, countries, COALESCE(SIZE(conflicts), 0) AS total_conflicts, COALESCE(SIZE(countries), 0) AS total_countries, [country IN countries | country.name] AS sorted_region_country_names WITH region_name, geo_region_UN_M49Code, total_countries, sorted_region_country_names, total_conflicts, classification, [co IN conflicts | co.name] AS conflict_name_list, [conflict IN conflicts | { conflict_name: COALESCE(conflict.name, "Unknown"), conflict_classification: classification, conflict_overview: COALESCE(conflict.overview, "No Overview Available"), applicable_ihl_law: COALESCE(conflict.applicable_law, "Not Specified"), conflict_citation: COALESCE(conflict.citation, "No Citation Available"), state_parties: CASE WHEN SIZE([ p IN all_actors WHERE "StateActor" IN labels(p) AND (p)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]->(conflict) ]) = 0 THEN "No state actors recorded" ELSE apoc.text.join([ p IN all_actors WHERE "StateActor" IN labels(p) AND (p)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]->(conflict) | p.name ], ", " ) END, non_state_parties: CASE WHEN SIZE([ p IN all_actors WHERE "NonStateActor" IN labels(p) AND (p)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]->(conflict) ]) = 0 THEN "No non-state actors recorded" ELSE apoc.text.join([ p IN all_actors WHERE "NonStateActor" IN labels(p) AND (p)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]->(conflict) | p.name ], ", " ) END } ] AS conflict_details WITH region_name, geo_region_UN_M49Code, total_countries, sorted_region_country_names, total_conflicts, classification, conflict_name_list, conflict_details, region_name + " is defined by UN M49 code " + geo_region_UN_M49Code + " and includes " + toString(total_countries) + " countries total: " + apoc.text.join(sorted_region_country_names, ", ") + "." AS region_summary, CASE WHEN total_conflicts = 0 THEN "According to RULAC, there are currently no recorded '" + classification + "' conflicts taking place in " + region_name + "." ELSE "According to RULAC, there are currently " + toString(total_conflicts) + " '" + classification + "' conflict(s) taking place in " + region_name + ": " + apoc.text.join(conflict_name_list, ", ") + "." END AS conflict_summary_text RETURN { summary: region_summary + " " + conflict_summary_text, conflict_details: CASE WHEN total_conflicts = 0 THEN [] ELSE conflict_details END } AS RULAC_research
Output:
The Sahel region, which includes parts of Western Africa, is currently experiencing several non-international armed conflicts. Based on the data provided, the active non-international armed conflicts in the Sahel region are:

1. **Non-International Armed Conflicts in Niger**
2. **Non-International Armed Conflicts in Mali**
3. **Non-International Armed Conflicts in Burkina Faso**

These conflicts involve various state and non-state actors, and they are classified as non-international armed conflicts under international humanitarian law.

country_name, total_conflicts, classification, conflict_name_list, conflicts, all_actors, [conflict IN conflicts | { conflict_name: COALESCE(conflict.name, "Unknown"), conflict_classification: classification, conflict_overview: COALESCE(conflict.overview, "No Overview Available"), applicable_ihl_law: COALESCE(conflict.applicable_law, "Not Specified"), conflict_citation: COALESCE(conflict.citation, "No Citation Available"), state_parties: CASE WHEN SIZE([ p IN all_actors WHERE "StateActor" IN labels(p) AND (p)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]->(conflict) ]) = 0 THEN "No state actors recorded" ELSE apoc.text.join([ p IN all_actors WHERE "StateActor" IN labels(p) AND (p)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]->(conflict) | p.name ], ", " ) END, non_state_parties: CASE WHEN SIZE([ p IN all_actors WHERE "NonStateActor" IN labels(p) AND (p)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]->(conflict) ]) = 0 THEN "No non-state actors recorded" ELSE apoc.text.join([ p IN all_actors WHERE "NonStateActor" IN labels(p) AND (p)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]->(conflict) | p.name ], ", " ) END } ] AS conflict_details WITH country_name, total_conflicts, classification, conflict_name_list, conflict_details, CASE WHEN total_conflicts = 0 THEN "According to RULAC, there are currently no recorded '" + classification + "' conflicts involving " + country_name + " as a state party." ELSE "According to RULAC, there are currently " + toString(total_conflicts) + " '" + classification + "' conflict(s) involving " + country_name + " as a state party: " + apoc.text.join(conflict_name_list, ", ") + "." END AS summary_text RETURN { summary: summary_text, conflict_details: CASE WHEN total_conflicts = 0 THEN [] ELSE conflict_details END } AS RULAC_research
Output:
Yes, there are currently two International Armed Conflicts (IACs) involving Türkiye:

1. **International Armed Conflicts in Syria**:
   - **Overview**: Syria is involved in multiple, parallel international armed conflicts against the US-led coalition, Türkiye, and Israel. Türkiye is occupying parts of northern Syria and has been conducting military operations against the Islamic State and Kurdish groups since 2016 without the consent of the Syrian government.
   - **Applicable Law**: Syria, Türkiye, the United States, and other members of the coalition are party to the four 1949 Geneva Conventions. Several countries, including Syria, are also party to the 1977 Additional Protocol I applicable to international armed conflicts. All parties are bound by customary international humanitarian law applicable to international armed conflicts.

2. **International Armed Conflict in Iraq**:
   - **Overview**: There is an international armed conflict between Türkiye and Iraq due to ongoing airstrikes by Türkiye targeting the Kurdistan Workers’ Party (PKK) in northern Iraq without the consent of the Iraqi government. This conflict is an extension of the ongoing non-international armed conflict in Türkiye between Turkish armed and security forces and the PKK.
   - **Applicable Law**: Both Iraq and Türkiye are party to the four 1949 Geneva Conventions. Iraq is also a party to the 1977 Additional Protocol I applicable to international armed conflicts. Both countries are bound by customary international humanitarian law applicable to international armed conflicts.

These conflicts highlight the complex nature of contemporary armed conflicts, involving multiple state and non-state actors and requiring careful legal classification under international humanitarian law.

### State Actors:
- **Rwanda**
- **Kenya**
- **Democratic Republic of the Congo**

- **Mai-Mai Yakutumba**
- **Allied Democratic Forces (ADF)**
- **CODECO**
- **M23**

The UN Organization Stabilization Mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (MONUSCO) is supporting the FARDC and is also a party to the conflicts. Rwanda has intervened in support of M23, and Kenya has deployed peacekeeping troops to DRC.

Output:
According to the research data provided, there is currently one military occupation recognized under International Humanitarian Law (IHL) in Palestine:

### Military Occupation of Palestine by Israel

**Conflict Overview:**
Israel is occupying the territory of Palestine. Israel is internationally recognized as the occupying power in the West Bank, including East Jerusalem, and the Gaza Strip. This occupation has been ongoing since the end of the Six-Day War in 1967. Despite the Oslo Accords, which divided direct authority over the West Bank between Israel and the Palestinian Authority, Israel retains effective control over the entire territory. Although Israel withdrew its ground forces from the Gaza Strip in 2005, it continues to be recognized as the occupying power due to the level of control it still exercises over the region.

**Applicable IHL Law:**
The law of military occupation is set forth in the 1907 Hague Convention (IV) Respecting the Laws and Customs of War on Land and its Annex, the 1949 Geneva Convention (IV) Relative to the Protection of Civilian Persons in Time of War, and the 1977 Additional Protocol I applicable to International Armed Conflicts. Israel is a party to the Geneva Convention (IV) but has not ratified the 1977 Additional Protocol I. Palestine acceded to the four 1949 Geneva Conventions, the 1977 Additional Protocol I, and the 1907 Hague Regulations in 2014. Customary international humanitarian law, including the Hague regulations, also applies.

**State Parties Involved:**
- Syrian Arab Republic
- Israel
- State of Palestine
- Lebanon

**Non-State Parties Involved:**
- Palestinian Islamic Jihad
- Hezbollah
- Hamas

This conflict is classified as a **Military Occupation**.

Output:
Based on the research data provided, there is one non-international armed conflict (NIAC) currently taking place in Latin America:

### Non-International Armed Conflicts in Colombia

**Conflict Overview:**
Colombia has experienced one of the longest non-international armed conflicts in modern times. Notably, the Government of Colombia is still involved in parallel NIACs against the Ejército de Liberación Nacional (National Liberation Army) (ELN) and the FARC-EP dissident group (Bloque Oriental (Eastern Bloc)).

**Applicable International Humanitarian Law:**
Colombia is a party to the four 1949 Geneva Conventions. All parties to the conflict are bound by Article 3 common to the 1949 Geneva Conventions, which provides for the minimum standards to be respected and requires humane treatment without adverse distinction of all persons not or no longer taking active part in hostilities. It prohibits murder, mutilation, torture, cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment, hostage-taking, and unfair trials.

Colombia is also a party to the 1977 Additional Protocol II (AP II) to the 1949 Geneva Conventions. According to Article 1, AP II, this treaty is applicable to NIACs taking place ‘in the territory of a High Contracting Party between its armed forces and dissident armed forces or other organized armed groups which, under responsible command, exercise such control over a part of its territory as to enable them to carry out sustained and concerted military operations and to implement this Protocol’. As discussed in the classification section, a number of non-state actors have an established command structure and control a considerable amount of the Colombian territory, hence AP II is applicable to the fight that involve these groups.

Moreover, all parties are bound by customary international humanitarian law applicable to non-international armed conflict.

In addition to international humanitarian law, international human rights law continues to apply during times of armed conflict. Under human rights law, the territorial state has an obligation to prevent and to investigate alleged violations, including by non-state actors. Non-state armed groups are increasingly considered to be bound by international human rights law if they exercise de facto control over some areas, such as the AGC.

**State Parties:**
Colombia

**Non-State Parties:**
- National Liberation Army (ELN)
- The former Bloque Oriental (Eastern Bloc) of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia– Ejército del Pueblo (Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia - People’s Army) (FARC-EP)

### Military Occupation of Cyprus by Türkiye

**Conflict Overview:**
Türkiye has occupied the northern part of Cyprus since July 1974. Türkiye is the occupying power in the northern part of Cyprus, exercising control through both the presence of its armed forces and the authority it exerts over the self-declared Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus, which is the de facto authority in the area.

**Applicable International Humanitarian Law:**
The law of military occupation is set out in the 1907 Hague Convention (IV) Respecting the Laws and Customs of War on Land and its Annex: Regulations Concerning the Laws and Customs on Land, the 1949 Geneva Conventions (IV) Relative to the Protection of Civilians Persons in Time of War, and the 1977 Additional Protocol I applicable to International Armed Conflicts. Both Cyprus and Türkiye are parties to the four 1949 Geneva Conventions, but only Cyprus is party to the 1977 Additional Protocol I. Customary international humanitarian law is also applicable during occupation; it complements the protection granted by treaties and binds all parties to the conflict. In addition to international humanitarian law, international human rights law continues to apply during times of occupation. Both Türkiye and Cyprus are parties to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the International Covenant on Economic, Social, and Cultural Rights, and the European Convention on Human Rights. Türkiye remains bound by its international human rights law obligations in the territory it occupies.

**State Parties Involved:**
- Cyprus
- Türkiye

**Conflict Classification:**
Military Occupation

**Non-State Parties Involved:**
No non-state actors recorded.

"Unknown"), conflict_classification: COALESCE([item IN conflict_types WHERE item.conflict = conf | item.type][0], "Unclassified"), conflict_overview: COALESCE(conf.overview, "No Overview Available"), (p)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]->(conf) | p.name], ", ") END, non_state_parties: CASE WHEN size([p IN all_actors WHERE "NonStateActor" IN labels(p) AND (p)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]->(conf)]) = 0 THEN "No Based on the research data provided, the Central African Republic is currently experiencing the following conflict:

### Non-International Armed Conflict

The Central African Republic is involved in a non-international armed conflict against various non-state actors, including ex-Séléka and anti-Balaka groups. The government is supported by the United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Mission (MINUSCA), Rwanda, the Wagner group, and previously by France. There are also parallel non-international armed conflicts between different armed groups.

The conflict involves multiple and overlapping non-international armed conflicts, with the government fighting against a wide array of rebel groups. The United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Mission in Central African Republic (MINUSCA) supports the government in stabilizing the country and securing main humanitarian and trade routes. France, Rwanda, and the Wagner group have also intervened in support of the government.

All parties to the conflict are bound by Article 3 common to the 1949 Geneva Conventions, which provides for the minimum standard of humane treatment without adverse distinction of all persons not or no longer taking active part in hostilities. It prohibits murder, mutilation, torture, cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment, hostage taking, and unfair trials. Additionally, all parties are bound by customary international humanitarian law applicable to non-international armed conflict. International human rights law also continues to apply during times of armed conflict.

Under human rights law, the territorial state has an obligation to prevent and investigate alleged violations, including by non-state actors. Non-state armed groups are increasingly considered to be bound by international human rights law if they exercise de facto control over some areas.

all_actors, c, ct WITH region_name, geo_region_UN_M49Code, state_actor_name, COUNT(DISTINCT c) AS total_conflicts_per_state_actor, CASE WHEN COUNT(DISTINCT c) = 0 THEN [] ELSE COLLECT(DISTINCT { conflict_name: COALESCE(c.name, "Unknown"), conflict_classification: COALESCE(ct.type, "Unclassified"), conflict_overview: COALESCE(c.overview, "No Overview Available"), applicable_ihl_law: COALESCE(c.applicable_law, "Not Specified"), conflict_citation: COALESCE(c.citation, "No Citation Available"), state_parties: CASE WHEN all_actors IS NULL OR size([p IN all_actors WHERE "StateActor" IN labels(p)]) = 0 THEN "No state actors recorded" ELSE apoc.text.join([p IN all_actors WHERE "StateActor" IN labels(p) | p.name], ", ") END, non_state_parties: CASE WHEN all_actors IS NULL OR size([p IN all_actors WHERE "NonStateActor" IN labels(p)]) = 0 THEN "No non-state actors recorded" ELSE apoc.text.join([p IN all_actors WHERE "NonStateActor" IN labels(p) | p.name], ", ") END }) END AS conflict_details WITH region_name, geo_region_UN_M49Code, state_actor_name, total_conflicts_per_state_actor, conflict_details, CASE WHEN total_conflicts_per_state_actor = 0 THEN "" ELSE apoc.text.join([conflict IN conflict_details | conflict.conflict_name], ", ") END AS conflict_names_per_state_actor WITH region_name, geo_region_UN_M49Code, COLLECT( CASE WHEN total_conflicts_per_state_actor = 0 THEN NULL ELSE toString(total_conflicts_per_state_actor) + " conflict(s) involving " + state_actor_name + ": " + conflict_names_per_state_actor END ) AS total_conflicts_by_state_actor, COLLECT(conflict_details) AS all_conflicts_per_state_actor WITH region_name, geo_region_UN_M49Code, [line IN total_conflicts_by_state_actor WHERE line IS NOT NULL] AS filtered_conflicts_by_state_actor, apoc.coll.flatten(all_conflicts_per_state_actor) AS conflict_details WITH region_name, geo_region_UN_M49Code, filtered_conflicts_by_state_actor, conflict_details, CASE WHEN conflict_details = [] THEN 0 ELSE size( apoc.coll.toSet( [d IN conflict_details | d.conflict_name] ) ) END AS total_distinct_conflicts RETURN { summary: CASE WHEN total_distinct_conflicts = 0 THEN "According to RULAC, there are currently no recorded armed conflicts " + "involving any state actors from " + region_name + " (UN M49 code: " + geo_region_UN_M49Code + ")." ELSE "According to RULAC, there are currently " + toString(total_distinct_conflicts) + " distinct armed conflict(s) involving state actors from " + region_name + " (UN M49 code: " + geo_region_UN_M49Code + "). " + "Breakdown by state actor: " + apoc.text.join(filtered_conflicts_by_state_actor, "; ") END, conflict_details: conflict_details } AS RULAC_research
Output:
Based on the research data provided, the following conflict in Latin America meets the threshold of Non-International Armed Conflicts (NIACs) under International Humanitarian Law (IHL):

### Non-International Armed Conflicts in Colombia

**Conflict Overview:**
Colombia has experienced one of the longest non-international armed conflicts in modern times. Notably, the Government of Colombia is still involved in parallel NIACs against the Ejército de Liberación Nacional (National Liberation Army) (ELN) and the FARC-EP dissident group (Bloque Oriental (Eastern Bloc)).

**Applicable IHL Law:**
Colombia is a party to the four 1949 Geneva Conventions. All parties to the conflict are bound by Article 3 common to the 1949 Geneva Conventions, which provides for the minimum standards to be respected and requires humane treatment without adverse distinction of all persons not or no longer taking active part in hostilities. It prohibits murder, mutilation, torture, cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment, hostage-taking, and unfair trials.

Colombia is also a party to the 1977 Additional Protocol II (AP II) to the 1949 Geneva Conventions. According to Article 1, AP II, this treaty is applicable to NIACs taking place ‘in the territory of a High Contracting Party between its armed forces and dissident armed forces or other organized armed groups which, under responsible command, exercise such control over a part of its territory as to enable them to carry out sustained and concerted military operations and to implement this Protocol’. As discussed in the classification section, a number of non-state actors have an established command structure and control a considerable amount of the Colombian territory, hence AP II is applicable to the fight that involve these groups.

Moreover, all parties are bound by customary international humanitarian law applicable to non-international armed conflict.

In addition to international humanitarian law, international human rights law continues to apply during times of armed conflict. Under human rights law, the territorial state has an obligation to prevent and to investigate alleged violations, including by non-state actors. Non-state armed groups are increasingly considered to be bound by international human rights law if they exercise de facto control over some areas, such as the AGC.

**State Parties:**
Colombia

**Non-State Parties:**
National Liberation Army (ELN), The former Bloque Oriental (Eastern Bloc) of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia– Ejército del Pueblo (Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia - People’s Army) (FARC-EP)

**Conflict Classification:**
Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)

Output:
According to the research data provided, there is currently one active armed conflict in Libya. This conflict is classified as a **Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)**.

### Conflict Details:
**Conflict Name:** Non-international armed conflicts in Libya

**Overview:**
After the fall of the Qaddafi regime in 2011, Libya has experienced continuous political unrest and armed violence. The situation is complicated by the presence of competing governments and a multitude of armed groups that frequently switch alliances and operate autonomously. Since 2014, there have been overlapping non-international armed conflicts involving the internationally recognized Government of Libya, the Libyan National Army (LNA), various armed groups, and intervening foreign powers.

Key points include:
- The UN-backed Government of National Accord (GNA) is engaged in conflicts with the self-declared LNA and groups loyal to General Haftar, who are aligned with the House of Representatives (HoR).
- The GNA is also fighting against groups pledging allegiance to the Islamic State, which gained control over Derna and Sirte in 2015.
- The LNA and its affiliated groups are fighting against the Islamic State and other armed groups, including the Derna Protection Force (DPF) and the Benghazi Revolutionaries Shura Council (BRSC).
- Foreign interventions include the United States launching an air campaign against the Islamic State in 2016, with Turkey supporting the GNA, and France and the United Arab Emirates supporting the LNA.

**Applicable International Humanitarian Law:**
Libya is a party to the four 1949 Geneva Conventions and Additional Protocol II, which applies to non-international armed conflicts. All parties to the conflict are bound by Article 3 common to the Geneva Conventions, which sets minimum standards for humane treatment and prohibits acts such as murder, torture, and unfair trials. Customary international humanitarian law also applies, and international human rights law continues to be relevant during the conflict.

**State Parties Involved:**
- United States of America
- United Arab Emirates
- France
- Türkiye
- Libya

**Non-State Parties Involved:**
- Libyan National Army
- Derna Protection Force (DPF)
- The Benghazi Revolutionaries Shura Council (BRSC)
- Islamic State group

Output:
Based on the research data provided, the following provisions of International Humanitarian Law (IHL) apply to conflicts in the Democratic Republic of the Congo:

### International Armed Conflict in Democratic Republic of Congo

- **Applicable IHL Law**:
  - The four 1949 Geneva Conventions
  - The 1977 Additional Protocol I applicable to international armed conflicts
  - Customary international humanitarian law applicable to international armed conflicts
  - International human rights law continues to apply during times of armed conflict, but it is controversial whether it also applies to extra-territorial airstrikes.

### Non-International Armed Conflicts in Democratic Republic of Congo

- **Applicable IHL Law**:
  - Article 3 common to the 1949 Geneva Conventions, which provides for minimum standards to be respected and requires humane treatment without adverse distinction of all persons not or no longer taking active part in hostilities. It prohibits murder, mutilation, torture, cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment, hostage taking and unfair trials.
  - Customary international humanitarian law applicable to non-international armed conflict.
  - International human rights law continues to apply during times of armed conflict. DRC is a party to the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights. Furthermore, it is bound by customary human rights law. Under human rights law, the territorial state has an obligation to prevent and investigate alleged violations, including by non-state actors. Non-state armed groups are increasingly considered to be bound by international human rights law if they exercise de facto control over some areas.

These provisions ensure that all parties involved in the conflicts adhere to the principles of IHL, protecting civilians and those who are no longer participating in hostilities.

International humanitarian law classifies conflicts involving Israel into several categories based on the nature of the conflicts and the parties involved. According to the data provided by RULAC, the conflicts involving Israel are classified as follows:

### International Armed Conflicts (IAC)
1. **International Armed Conflicts in Syria**:
   - **Conflict Overview**: Syria is involved in multiple, parallel international armed conflicts against the so-called ‘Global Coalition’ (led by the United States), Türkiye, and Israel. Israel has been targeting Iranian and Hezbollah objectives in Syria, in addition to Syrian forces and military targets.
   - **Applicable Law**: The law governing international armed conflicts, including the 1949 Geneva Conventions and customary international humanitarian law.

### Military Occupations
1. **Military Occupation of Syria by Israel**:
   - **Conflict Overview**: Since June 1967, Israel has occupied the Golan Heights, over which Syria is recognized as sovereign.
   - **Applicable Law**: The law of military occupation as set out in the 1907 Hague Convention (IV) and the 1949 Geneva Conventions (IV).

2. **Military Occupation of Palestine by Israel**:
   - **Conflict Overview**: Israel is occupying the territory of Palestine, including the West Bank, East Jerusalem, and the Gaza Strip. This occupation has been ongoing since the end of the Six-Day War in 1967.
   - **Applicable Law**: The law of military occupation as set out in the 1907 Hague Convention (IV) and the 1949 Geneva Conventions (IV).

3. **Military Occupation of Lebanon by Israel**:
   - **Conflict Overview**: Since the Six-Day War of 1967, Israel has occupied the Shebaa Farms, which is recognized as part of Lebanon.
   - **Applicable Law**: The law of military occupation as set out in the 1907 Hague Convention (IV) and the 1949 Geneva Conventions (IV).

### Non-International Armed Conflicts (NIAC)
- **Clashes between Israel and Hezbollah**:
  - **Conflict Overview**: The clashes between Israel and Hezbollah amount to a non-international armed conflict in addition to the international armed conflicts between Israel and Lebanon and between Israel and Syria.
  - **Applicable Law**: Customary international humanitarian law applicable to non-international armed conflicts.

### Summary
- **Total International Armed Conflicts**: 1
- **Total Military Occupations**: 3
- **Total Non-International Armed Conflicts**: 1

These classifications are based on the legal criteria and facts as determined by international humanitarian law. The classification of a situation as an armed conflict has important consequences, including the applicability of international humanitarian law and the rights and duties of the parties involved.

The African Union Transition Mission in Somalia (ATMIS) supports the Somali government, and Ethiopian armed forces operate independently in the country. The United States also conducts ground and air operations against al-Shabaab.

These conflicts are classified based on the criteria set forth by international humanitarian law, which distinguishes between international and non-international armed conflicts.

According to the RULAC research data, India is involved in three distinct armed conflicts. Here are the details:

### International Armed Conflicts

1. **International Armed Conflict between India and China**
   - **Classification**: International Armed Conflict (IAC)
   - **Overview**: This conflict revolves around the control of two main regions, Aksai Chin and Arunachal Pradesh, along with several smaller regions along the Sino-Indian border.
   - **Applicable Law**: Both India and China are party to the four 1949 Geneva Conventions and are bound by customary international humanitarian law.

2. **International Armed Conflict between India and Pakistan**
   - **Classification**: International Armed Conflict (IAC)
   - **Overview**: The conflict centers on the disputed status of Kashmir, which has been a source of tension since the first Indo-Pakistan war in 1947. Recent years have seen an increase in ceasefire violations and border skirmishes.
   - **Applicable Law**: Both India and Pakistan are party to the four 1949 Geneva Conventions and are bound by customary international humanitarian law.

### Non-International Armed Conflict

1. **Non-International Armed Conflict in India**
   - **Classification**: Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)
   - **Overview**: The Government of India is engaged in a conflict with the Communist Party of India-Maoist (Naxalites), which has been ongoing since the late 2000s. Additionally, there is a conflict with separatist groups in Indian-administered Jammu and Kashmir (J&K).
   - **Applicable Law**: All parties are bound by Article 3 common to the 1949 Geneva Conventions and customary international humanitarian law. International human rights law also continues to apply during the conflict.

These classifications are based on the criteria set forth by international humanitarian law and reflect the current status of the conflicts as reported by RULAC.

Output:
Based on the research data provided, the conflicts involving Saudi Arabia are governed by the following international treaties:

### International Armed Conflicts in Syria
- **Four 1949 Geneva Conventions**: Saudi Arabia, along with other members of the coalition, is a party to these conventions.
- **1977 Additional Protocol I**: This protocol is applicable to international armed conflicts and is binding on Saudi Arabia and other members of the coalition.
- **Customary International Humanitarian Law**: This applies to international armed conflicts and is binding on all parties involved.

### Non-International Armed Conflicts in Yemen
- **Four 1949 Geneva Conventions**: Yemen is a party to these conventions, and all parties to the conflict are bound by Article 3 common to the Geneva Conventions.
- **1977 Additional Protocol II**: This protocol is applicable to non-international armed conflicts and is binding on Yemen. The Houthis and al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula are considered to fulfill the required criteria for the applicability of Protocol II.
- **Customary International Humanitarian Law**: This applies to non-international armed conflicts and is binding on all parties involved.

### Non-International Armed Conflicts in Syria
- **Four 1949 Geneva Conventions**: All parties to the conflict are bound by Article 3 common to the Geneva Conventions.
- **Customary International Humanitarian Law**: This applies to non-international armed conflicts and is binding on all parties involved.

In addition to international humanitarian law, international human rights law continues to apply during times of armed conflict. This means that the territorial state has an obligation to prevent and investigate alleged violations, including by non-state actors. Non-state armed groups are increasingly considered to be bound by international human rights law if they exercise de facto control over some areas.

### Non-International Armed Conflicts

     - **Customary International Humanitarian Law**
     - **International Human Rights Law** (applicable during times of armed conflict, with the territorial state having an obligation to prevent and investigate alleged violations, including by non-state actors)

These legal frameworks govern the conduct of the parties involved in these conflicts, ensuring the protection of civilians and the humane treatment of all individuals affected by the hostilities.

2. **Military Occupation of Ukraine by Russia**
   - **Conflict Type:** Military Occupation
   - **Overview:** Russia has been occupying Crimea since March 2014 and large territories in the south and east of Ukraine since February 2022.

3. **International Armed Conflict in Ukraine**
   - **Conflict Type:** International Armed Conflict (IAC)
   - **Overview:** There has been an ongoing international armed conflict between Russia and Ukraine since February 2014, with a new phase starting in February 2022 when Russia invaded Ukraine.

4. **Military Occupation of Moldova by Russia**
   - **Conflict Type:** Military Occupation
   - **Overview:** Russia occupies part of Moldovan territory, specifically Transdniestria, and exercises overall control over the separatist armed groups in the region.

5. **Non-International Armed Conflicts in Syria**
   - **Conflict Type:** Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)
   - **Overview:** Multiple and overlapping non-international armed conflicts are occurring in Syria, involving various rebel groups and foreign state forces, including Russia.

### Conflicts Involving Ukraine

1. **Military Occupation of Ukraine by Russia**
   - **Conflict Type:** Military Occupation
   - **Overview:** Russia has been occupying Crimea since March 2014 and large territories in the south and east of Ukraine since February 2022.

2. **International Armed Conflict in Ukraine**
   - **Conflict Type:** International Armed Conflict (IAC)
   - **Overview:** There has been an ongoing international armed conflict between Russia and Ukraine since February 2014, with a new phase starting in February 2022 when Russia invaded Ukraine.

### Summary

- **Russia:** 5 conflicts
- **Ukraine:** 2 conflicts

Thus, Russia has been involved in more armed conflicts than Ukraine since 2014.

### Ethiopia
1. **Non-international armed conflict in Somalia**

The African Union Transition Mission in Somalia (ATMIS) supports the Somali government, and Kenyan and Ethiopian armed forces operate independently in the country. The United States also conducts ground and air operations against al-Shabaab.
   - **Applicable IHL Law**: All parties are bound by Article 3 common to the 1949 Geneva Conventions and customary international humanitarian law applicable to non-international armed conflict.
   - **State Parties**: Somalia, Ethiopia, Kenya, United States of America
   - **Non-State Parties**: Islamic State in Somalia (ISS), Al-Shabaab, African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM)

2. **Non-international armed conflicts in Ethiopia**
   - **Conflict Overview**: The Ethiopian central government is engaged in a non-international armed conflict against the Oromo Liberation Army (OLA) and was previously involved in a conflict against the Tigray People’s Liberation Front (TPLF). Eritrean troops were also reported to be fighting against the non-state forces.
   - **Applicable IHL Law**: All parties are bound by Article 3 common to the 1949 Geneva Conventions and customary international humanitarian law applicable to non-international armed conflict.
   - **State Parties**: Ethiopia
   - **Non-State Parties**: Oromo Liberation Army (OLA), Tigray People's Liberation Front (TPLF)

### Sudan
1. **Non-international armed conflicts in Sudan**
   - **Conflict Overview**: Several parallel non-international armed conflicts are taking place in Sudan. The government is involved in conflicts against factions of the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army–Abdel Wahid (SLM/A–AW) and the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement/Army–North (SPLM–North). Additionally, since April 2023, the government has been engaging in a NIAC against the Rapid Support Forces (RSF).
   - **Applicable IHL Law**: All parties are bound by Article 3 common to the 1949 Geneva Conventions and customary international humanitarian law applicable to non-international armed conflict.
   - **State Parties**: Sudan
   - **Non-State Parties**: The Sudan People’s Liberation Movement/Army–North Hilu (SPLM/A–N Hilu), The Sudan People’s Liberation Movement/Army–North Agar (SPLM-North Agar), Rapid Support Forces (RSF), The Sudan Liberation Movement/Army–Abdel Wahid (SLM/A–AW)

2. **Non-international armed conflicts in Yemen**
   - **Conflict Overview**: Multiple parallel and overlapping non-international armed conflicts are taking place in Yemen, involving the government and various non-state armed groups. The government is supported by an international coalition led by Saudi Arabia.
   - **Applicable IHL Law**: All parties are bound by Article 3 common to the 1949 Geneva Conventions and customary international humanitarian law applicable to non-international armed conflict.
   - **State Parties**: Sudan, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain, United Arab Emirates, United States of America, Egypt, Yemen, Jordan
   - **Non-State Parties**: Houthi, Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, Southern Transitional Council (STC)

In summary, both Ethiopia and Sudan are involved in two non-international armed conflicts each.

Based on the data provided by RULAC, both India and Pakistan are party to an equal number of internationally recognized armed conflicts. Each country is involved in three armed conflicts.

### India's Involvement in Armed Conflicts

1. **International Armed Conflict between India and China**
   - **Conflict Overview**: India and China are involved in an international armed conflict over the control of two main regions, namely Aksai Chin and Arunachal Pradesh, and a number of smaller regions along the Sino-Indian border.
   - **Applicable IHL Law**: Both countries are party to the four 1949 Geneva Conventions and are bound by customary international humanitarian law.

2. **International Armed Conflict between India and Pakistan**
   - **Conflict Overview**: India and Pakistan are involved in an international armed conflict over the status of Kashmir. The disputed status of Kashmir has been a source of conflict between India and Pakistan since the first Indo-Pakistan war in 1947.
   - **Applicable IHL Law**: Both countries are party to the four 1949 Geneva Conventions and are bound by customary international humanitarian law.

3. **Non-International Armed Conflict in India**
   - **Conflict Overview**: The Government of India is involved in a non-international armed conflict with the Communist Party of India-Maoist, a non-state armed group. There is also a non-international armed conflict between India and separatist groups in Indian-administered Jammu and Kashmir (J&K).
   - **Applicable IHL Law**: All parties to the conflict are bound by Article 3 common to the 1949 Geneva Conventions and customary international humanitarian law applicable to non-international armed conflicts.

### Pakistan's Involvement in Armed Conflicts

1. **International Armed Conflict between Afghanistan and Pakistan**
   - **Conflict Overview**: Since October 2021, Pakistan and Afghanistan have engaged in border clashes.
   - **Applicable IHL Law**: Both countries are parties to the four 1949 Geneva Conventions and to the 1977 Additional Protocol I applicable to international armed conflicts. They are also bound by customary international humanitarian law.

2. **Non-International Armed Conflicts in Pakistan**
   - **Conflict Overview**: There are multiple and overlapping armed conflicts in Pakistan, including conflicts with the Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan group (TTP), armed groups fighting for the independence of the province of Balochistan, and other non-state armed groups.
   - **Applicable IHL Law**: All parties to the conflict are bound by Article 3 common to the 1949 Geneva Conventions and customary international humanitarian law applicable to non-international armed conflicts.

3. **International Armed Conflict between India and Pakistan**
   - **Conflict Overview**: India and Pakistan are involved in an international armed conflict over the status of Kashmir. The disputed status of Kashmir has been a source of conflict between India and Pakistan since the first Indo-Pakistan war in 1947.
   - **Applicable IHL Law**: Both countries are party to the four 1949 Geneva Conventions and are bound by customary international humanitarian law.

In summary, both India and Pakistan are involved in three internationally recognized armed conflicts each, making their engagement in armed conflicts equal in number.

Based on the data provided by RULAC, the following armed conflicts involve France, Israel, or the United States:

#### France

1. **Non-International Armed Conflicts in the Central African Republic**
   - **Conflict Type:** Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)
   - **Overview:** France has been involved in supporting the Central African Republic government against various rebel groups, including the anti-Balaka and ex-Séléka groups.

2. **Non-International Armed Conflicts in Niger**
   - **Conflict Type:** Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)
   - **Overview:** France has been present in Niger since July 2022, supporting the government against non-state armed groups like Boko Haram and the Islamic State in West Africa Province (ISWAP).

3. **International Armed Conflicts in Syria**
   - **Conflict Type:** International Armed Conflict (IAC)
   - **Overview:** France is part of the US-led coalition against the Syrian government and other non-state actors.

4. **Non-International Armed Conflicts in Burkina Faso**
   - **Conflict Type:** Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)
   - **Overview:** France has been militarily active in Burkina Faso since 2014, engaging in conflicts against jihadist groups.

5. **Non-International Armed Conflicts in Syria**
   - **Conflict Type:** Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)
   - **Overview:** France is involved in parallel non-international armed conflicts against various rebel groups and non-state actors.

6. **Non-International Armed Conflicts in Libya**
   - **Conflict Type:** Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)
   - **Overview:** France is involved in supporting the Libyan National Army (LNA) against various armed groups.

#### Israel

1. **Military Occupation of Syria by Israel**
   - **Conflict Type:** Military Occupation
   - **Overview:** Israel has occupied the Golan Heights since 1967, which is recognized as sovereign Syrian territory.

2. **International Armed Conflicts in Syria**
   - **Conflict Type:** International Armed Conflict (IAC)
   - **Overview:** Israel has been involved in military operations against Iranian and Hezbollah objectives in Syria.

3. **Military Occupation of Palestine by Israel**
   - **Conflict Type:** Military Occupation
   - **Overview:** Israel occupies the West Bank, including East Jerusalem, and the Gaza Strip, with ongoing conflicts with groups like Hamas and Hezbollah.

4. **Military Occupation of Lebanon by Israel**
   - **Conflict Type:** Military Occupation
   - **Overview:** Israel has occupied the Shebaa Farms since 1967, which is recognized as part of Lebanon.

5. **Non-International Armed Conflicts in Syria**
   - **Conflict Type:** Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)
   - **Overview:** Israel is involved in conflicts against Hezbollah and other non-state actors in Syria.

#### United States of America

1. **Non-International Armed Conflicts in Syria**
   - **Conflict Type:** Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)
   - **Overview:** The United States is involved in conflicts against various rebel groups and non-state actors.

2. **Non-International Armed Conflicts in Yemen**
   - **Conflict Type:** Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)
   - **Overview:** The United States supports the Yemeni government against the Houthis and other armed groups.

3. **International Armed Conflicts in Syria**
   - **Conflict Type:** International Armed Conflict (IAC)
   - **Overview:** The United States leads a coalition against the Syrian government and other non-state actors.

4. **Non-International Armed Conflict in Somalia**
   - **Conflict Type:** Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)
   - **Overview:** The United States conducts operations against al-Shabaab and provides support to Somali security forces.

5. **Non-International Armed Conflicts in Libya**
   - **Conflict Type:** Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)
   - **Overview:** The United States launched an air campaign against the Islamic State group and continues to support the Government of National Accord (GNA).

Input: What conflicts involve state actors from the Horn of Africa?
Generated Query: WITH ["262", "232", "231", "706"] AS target_country_codes OPTIONAL MATCH (sa:StateActor)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]->(c:Conflict) WHERE sa.UN_M49Code IN target_country_codes OPTIONAL MATCH (c)-[:IS_CLASSIFIED_AS_CONFLICT_TYPE]->(ct:ConflictType) OPTIONAL MATCH (c)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]-(actor) WITH sa.name AS state_actor_name, COLLECT(DISTINCT actor) AS all_actors, c, ct WITH state_actor_name, COUNT(DISTINCT c) AS total_conflicts_per_state_actor, CASE WHEN COUNT(DISTINCT c) = 0 THEN [] ELSE COLLECT(DISTINCT { conflict_name: COALESCE(c.name, "Unknown"), conflict_classification: COALESCE(ct.type, "Unclassified"), conflict_overview: COALESCE(c.overview, "No Overview Available"), applicable_ihl_law: COALESCE(c.applicable_law, "Not Specified"), conflict_citation: COALESCE(c.citation, "No Citation Available"), state_parties: CASE WHEN all_actors IS NULL OR size([p IN all_actors WHERE "StateActor" IN labels(p)]) = 0 THEN "No state actors recorded" ELSE apoc.text.join([p IN all_actors WHERE "StateActor" IN labels(p) | p.name], ", ") END, non_state_parties: CASE WHEN all_actors IS NULL OR size([p IN all_actors WHERE "NonStateActor" IN labels(p)]) = 0 THEN "No non-state actors recorded" ELSE apoc.text.join([p IN all_actors WHERE "NonStateActor" IN labels(p) | p.name], ", ") END }) END AS conflict_details WITH state_actor_name, total_conflicts_per_state_actor, conflict_details, CASE WHEN total_conflicts_per_state_actor = 0 THEN "" ELSE apoc.text.join([conflict IN conflict_details | conflict.conflict_name], ", ") END AS conflict_names_per_state_actor WITH COLLECT( CASE WHEN total_conflicts_per_state_actor = 0 THEN NULL ELSE toString(total_conflicts_per_state_actor) + " conflict(s) involving " + state_actor_name + ": " + conflict_names_per_state_actor END ) AS total_conflicts_by_state_actor, COLLECT(conflict_details) AS all_conflicts_per_state_actor WITH [line IN total_conflicts_by_state_actor WHERE line IS NOT NULL] AS filtered_conflicts_by_state_actor, apoc.coll.flatten(all_conflicts_per_state_actor) AS conflict_details WITH filtered_conflicts_by_state_actor, conflict_details, CASE WHEN conflict_details = [] THEN 0 ELSE size( apoc.coll.toSet( [d IN conflict_details | d.conflict_name] ) ) END AS total_distinct_conflicts RETURN { summary: CASE WHEN total_distinct_conflicts = 0 THEN "According to RULAC, there are currently no recorded armed conflicts " + "involving any state actors from the Horn of Africa region, which is defined by the following countries: Djibouti, Eritrea, Ethiopia, and Somalia." ELSE "According to RULAC, there are currently " + toString(total_distinct_conflicts) + " distinct armed conflict(s) involving state actors from the Horn of Africa region, which is defined by the following countries: Djibouti, Eritrea, Ethiopia, and Somalia. " + "Breakdown by state actor: " + apoc.text.join(filtered_conflicts_by_state_actor, "; ") END, conflict_details: conflict_details } AS RULAC_research
Output:
Based on the research data provided, there are currently two distinct armed conflicts involving state actors from the Horn of Africa region. The Horn of Africa includes the countries of Djibouti, Eritrea, Ethiopia, and Somalia. Here are the details of the conflicts:

### Conflicts Involving State Actors from the Horn of Africa

#### Non-International Armed Conflict in Somalia

**State Actors Involved:**
- Somalia
- Ethiopia
- Kenya
- United States of America

**Non-State Actors Involved:**
- Islamic State in Somalia (ISS)
- Al-Shabaab
- African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM)

**Overview:**
This conflict involves the internationally recognized federal government of Somalia fighting against Islamist insurgents, most prominently the armed group al-Shabaab, which has pledged allegiance to al-Qaeda. The African Union Transition Mission in Somalia (ATMIS), previously known as AMISOM, is a peacekeeping operation supporting the Somali government. In addition to contributing troops to AMISOM, Kenyan and Ethiopian armed forces also operate independently in the country. The United States conducts ground and air operations against al-Shabaab and provides material support to AMISOM and Somali security forces. The conflict involving al-Shabaab has spilled over into Kenya.

**Applicable International Humanitarian Law:**
All parties to the conflict are bound by Article 3 common to the 1949 Geneva Conventions, which provides for the minimum standard to be respected and requires humane treatment without adverse distinction of all persons not or no longer taking active part in hostilities. It prohibits murder, mutilation, torture, cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment, hostage taking, and unfair trials. Additionally, all parties are bound by customary international humanitarian law applicable to non-international armed conflict. International human rights law continues to apply during times of armed conflict.

#### Non-International Armed Conflicts in Ethiopia

**State Actors Involved:**
- Ethiopia

**Non-State Actors Involved:**
- Oromo Liberation Army (OLA)
- Tigray People's Liberation Front (TPLF)

**Overview:**
The Ethiopian central government has been engaging in a non-international armed conflict against the Oromo Liberation Army (OLA). Furthermore, Ethiopia was party to a non-international armed conflict against the Tigray People’s Liberation Front (TPLF). It has been reported that Eritrean troops were also fighting against the non-state forces.

**Applicable International Humanitarian Law:**
All parties to the conflict are bound by Article 3 common to the 1949 Geneva Conventions, which provides for the minimum standards to be respected and requires humane treatment without adverse distinction of all persons not or no longer taking active parts in hostilities. It prohibits murder, mutilation, torture, cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment, hostage taking, and unfair trials. All parties are also bound by customary international humanitarian law applicable to non-international armed conflict. International human rights law continues to apply during times of armed conflict.

These conflicts highlight the complex nature of armed violence in the Horn of Africa, involving both state and non-state actors and requiring adherence to international humanitarian law.

" + "Breakdown by state actor: " + apoc.text.join(filtered_state_summaries, "; ") END, conflict_details: conflict_details } AS RULAC_research
Output:
Yes, there is one Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC) involving a state actor from South America. The conflict is:

### Non-International Armed Conflicts in Colombia

**Conflict Overview:**
Colombia has experienced one of the longest non-international armed conflicts in modern times. Notably, the Government of Colombia is still involved in parallel NIACs against the Ejército de Liberación Nacional (National Liberation Army) (ELN) and the FARC-EP dissident group (Bloque Oriental (Eastern Bloc)).

**Applicable International Humanitarian Law:**
Colombia is a party to the four 1949 Geneva Conventions. All parties to the conflict are bound by Article 3 common to the 1949 Geneva Conventions, which provides for the minimum standards to be respected and requires humane treatment without adverse distinction of all persons not or no longer taking active part in hostilities. It prohibits murder, mutilation, torture, cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment, hostage-taking and unfair trials.

Colombia is also a party to the 1977 Additional Protocol II (AP II) to the 1949 Geneva Conventions. According to Article 1, AP II, this treaty is applicable to NIACs taking place ‘in the territory of a High Contracting Party between its armed forces and dissident armed forces or other organized armed groups which, under responsible command, exercise such control over a part of its territory as to enable them to carry out sustained and concerted military operations and to implement this Protocol’. As discussed in the classification section, a number of non-state actors have an established command structure and control a considerable amount of the Colombian territory, hence AP II is applicable to the fight that involve these groups.

Moreover, all parties are bound by customary international humanitarian law applicable to non-international armed conflict.

In addition to international humanitarian law, international human rights law continues to apply during times of armed conflict. Under human rights law, the territorial state has an obligation to prevent and to investigate alleged violations, including by non-state actors. Non-state armed groups are increasingly considered to be bound by international human rights law if they exercise de facto control over some areas, such as the AGC.

**State Parties:**
Colombia

**Non-State Parties:**
National Liberation Army (ELN), The former Bloque Oriental (Eastern Bloc) of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia– Ejército del Pueblo (Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia - People’s Army) (FARC-EP)

The Horn of Africa, which includes Djibouti, Eritrea, Ethiopia, and Somalia, has the following conflicts:

1. **Non-international armed conflict in Somalia**

   - **Non-State Parties:** Islamic State in Somalia (ISS), Al-Shabaab, African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM)

2. **Non-international armed conflicts in Ethiopia**
   - **State Parties:** Ethiopia
   - **Non-State Parties:** Oromo Liberation Army (OLA), Tigray People's Liberation Front (TPLF)

### Conflicts in the Sahel

The Sahel region, which includes Senegal, Mauritania, Mali, Burkina Faso, Niger, Chad, and Sudan, has the following conflicts:

1. **Non-International Armed Conflict in Senegal**
   - **State Parties:** Senegal
   - **Non-State Parties:** MFDC- Front Sud

2. **Non-international armed conflicts in Mali**
   - **State Parties:** Mali
   - **Non-State Parties:** Islamic State in the Greater Sahara (ISGS), Jama'at Nusrat al-Islam wal-Muslimin (JNIM)

3. **Non-international armed conflicts in Burkina Faso**
   - **State Parties:** France, Burkina Faso
   - **Non-State Parties:** Islamic State in the Greater Sahara (ISGS), Group for the Support of Islam and Muslims (JNIM), Islamic State in West Africa Province (ISWAP), Ansaroul Islam

4. **Non-International Armed Conflicts in Niger**
   - **State Parties:** France, Niger
   - **Non-State Parties:** ISWAP, Multinational Joint Task Force (MNJTF), Boko Haram

5. **Non-International Armed Conflicts in Nigeria**
   - **State Parties:** Niger, Benin, Cameroon, Chad, Nigeria
   - **Non-State Parties:** Islamic State in West Africa Province (ISWAP), Boko Haram

6. **Non-International Armed Conflict in Chad**
   - **State Parties:** Chad
   - **Non-State Parties:** Boko Haram

7. **Non-international armed conflicts in Sudan**
   - **State Parties:** Sudan
   - **Non-State Parties:** The Sudan People’s Liberation Movement/Army–North Hilu (SPLM/A–N Hilu), The Sudan People’s Liberation Movement/Army–North Agar (SPLM-North Agar), Rapid Support Forces (RSF), The Sudan Liberation Movement/Army–Abdel Wahid (SLM/A–AW)

8. **Non-international armed conflicts in Yemen**
   - **State Parties:** Sudan, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain, United Arab Emirates, United States of America, Egypt, Yemen, Jordan
   - **Non-State Parties:** Houthi, Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, Southern Transitional Council (STC)

### Total Conflicts

- **Horn of Africa:** 2 conflicts
- **Sahel:** 8 conflicts

Thus, the Sahel region has seen more conflicts in the past decade.

" + "Among these, " + toString(regionB.number_of_state_actors_involved) + " state actor(s) are currently involved as a state party to conflict(s): " + apoc.text.join([ab IN regionB.actor_breakdown WHERE ab.total_conflicts > 0 | ab.actor_name + " is state party to " + toString(ab.total_conflicts) + " conflict(s): " + apoc.text.join(ab.conflict_names, ", ")], " ") END ), conflict_details: all_conflict_details } AS RULAC_research
Output:
Based on the provided research data from RULAC, we can determine the number of cross-border conflicts in both Western Africa and Eastern Africa.

### Western Africa

Western Africa includes the following states: Togo, Sierra Leone, Senegal, Saint Helena, Nigeria, Niger, Mauritania, Mali, Liberia, Guinea-Bissau, Guinea, Ghana, Gambia, Côte d’Ivoire, Cabo Verde, Burkina Faso, and Benin. Among these, the conflicts involving cross-border elements are:

1. **Non-International Armed Conflicts in Nigeria**
   - **Conflict Overview**: Involves Nigeria, Niger, Chad, Cameroon, and Benin against Boko Haram and ISWAP.
   - **Conflict Classification**: Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)

2. **Non-International Armed Conflicts in Niger**
   - **Conflict Overview**: Involves Niger and France against Boko Haram and ISWAP.
   - **Conflict Classification**: Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)

3. **Non-international armed conflicts in Mali**
   - **Conflict Overview**: Involves Mali, France, and the United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (MINUSMA) against various non-state armed groups.
   - **Conflict Classification**: Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)

4. **Non-international armed conflicts in Burkina Faso**
   - **Conflict Overview**: Involves Burkina Faso and France against various jihadist groups.
   - **Conflict Classification**: Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)

### Eastern Africa

Eastern Africa includes the following states: Eritrea, British Indian Ocean Territory, Zimbabwe, Zambia, United Republic of Tanzania, Uganda, South Sudan, Somalia, Seychelles, Rwanda, Réunion, Mozambique, Mayotte, Mauritius, Malawi, Madagascar, Kenya, French Southern Territories, Ethiopia, Djibouti, Comoros, and Burundi. Among these, the conflicts involving cross-border elements are:

1. **Non-International Armed Conflicts in Mozambique**
   - **Conflict Overview**: Involves Mozambique, United Republic of Tanzania, Rwanda, and the Southern African Development Community Mission (SAMIM) against Al-Shabaab.
   - **Conflict Classification**: Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)

2. **Non-international armed conflict in Somalia**
   - **Conflict Overview**: Involves Somalia, Ethiopia, Kenya, and the United States against Al-Shabaab and other non-state armed groups.
   - **Conflict Classification**: Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)

3. **Non-international Armed Conflicts in Democratic Republic of Congo**
   - **Conflict Overview**: Involves the Democratic Republic of Congo, Rwanda, and Kenya against various non-state armed groups.
   - **Conflict Classification**: Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)

4. **International Armed Conflict in Democratic Republic of Congo**
   - **Conflict Overview**: Involves the Democratic Republic of Congo and Rwanda.
   - **Conflict Classification**: International Armed Conflict (IAC)

5. **Non-international armed conflicts in the Central African Republic**
   - **Conflict Overview**: Involves the Central African Republic, Rwanda, and France against various non-state armed groups.
   - **Conflict Classification**: Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)

6. **Non-international armed conflict in Kenya**
   - **Conflict Overview**: Involves Kenya against Al-Shabaab, with Kenyan troops also operating in Somalia.
   - **Conflict Classification**: Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)

7. **Non-international armed conflicts in Ethiopia**
   - **Conflict Overview**: Involves Ethiopia against the Oromo Liberation Army (OLA) and the Tigray People’s Liberation Front (TPLF), with reported involvement of Eritrean troops.
   - **Conflict Classification**: Non-International Armed Conflict (NIAC)

### Conclusion

Eastern Africa has more cross-border conflicts than Western Africa. Eastern Africa has a total of 7 cross-border conflicts, while Western Africa has 4.

Category: 9. Ranking most / least global country conflict involvement across world
Input: Which five countries have been involved in the highest number of armed conflicts since 2000?
Generated Query: MATCH (sa:StateActor)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]->(c:Conflict) OPTIONAL MATCH (c)-[:IS_CLASSIFIED_AS_CONFLICT_TYPE]->(ct:ConflictType) OPTIONAL MATCH (c)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]-(actor) WITH sa.name AS state_actor, c, ct, COLLECT(DISTINCT {name: actor.name, labels: labels(actor)}) AS conflict_parties WITH state_actor, COUNT(DISTINCT c) AS total_conflicts, COLLECT({conflict_name: c.name, conflict_classification: ct.type, conflict_overview: c.overview, applicable_ihl_law: c.applicable_law, conflict_citation: c.citation, state_parties: CASE WHEN SIZE([p IN conflict_parties WHERE "StateActor" IN p.labels]) = 0 THEN "No state actors recorded" ELSE apoc.text.join([p IN conflict_parties WHERE "StateActor" IN p.labels | p.name], ", ") END, non_state_parties: CASE WHEN SIZE([p IN conflict_parties WHERE "NonStateActor" IN p.labels]) = 0 THEN "No non-state actors recorded" ELSE apoc.text.join([p IN conflict_parties WHERE "NonStateActor" IN p.labels | p.name], ", ") END}) AS conflict_details ORDER BY total_conflicts DESC LIMIT 5 WITH COLLECT({state_actor: state_actor, total_conflicts: total_conflicts, conflict_details: conflict_details}) AS state_actor_data, apoc.coll.flatten(COLLECT(conflict_details)) AS conflict_details WITH state_actor_data, conflict_details, [entry IN state_actor_data | entry.state_actor + " is an official state actor engaged in " + toString(entry.total_conflicts) + " conflicts (" + apoc.text.join([conflict IN entry.conflict_details | conflict.conflict_name], ", ") + ")"] AS summary_list RETURN {summary: "According to RULAC, the top 5 countries currently party to the most conflicts are, in order of involvement: " + apoc.text.join(summary_list, "; ") + ".", state_actor_data: state_actor_data, conflict_details: conflict_details} AS RULAC_research
Output:
Based on the research data provided, the five countries that have been involved in the highest number of armed conflicts since 2000 are:

1. **Türkiye** - 8 conflicts
2. **France** - 6 conflicts
3. **Syrian Arab Republic** - 5 conflicts
4. **United States of America** - 5 conflicts
5. **Russian Federation** - 5 conflicts

These countries are involved in a mix of international armed conflicts, non-international armed conflicts, and military occupations.

Category: 9. Ranking most / least global country conflict involvement across world
Input: Which countries are not currently involved in an armed conflict?
Generated Query: WITH "001" AS target_region_code, "World" AS target_region_name MATCH (gr:GeoRegion {UN_M49Code: target_region_code}) OPTIONAL MATCH (co:Country)-[:BELONGS_TO]->(gr) OPTIONAL MATCH (co)<-[:IS_TAKING_PLACE_IN_COUNTRY]-(c:Conflict) OPTIONAL MATCH (c)-[:IS_CLASSIFIED_AS_CONFLICT_TYPE]->(ct:ConflictType) OPTIONAL MATCH (c)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]-(actor) WITH COALESCE(gr.name, target_region_name) AS region_name, COALESCE(gr.UN_M49Code, target_region_code) AS geo_region_UN_M49Code, COALESCE(COLLECT(DISTINCT co), []) AS countries, COALESCE(COLLECT(DISTINCT c), []) AS conflicts, COALESCE(COLLECT(DISTINCT actor), []) AS all_actors, COALESCE(COLLECT(DISTINCT {conflict: c, type: ct.type}), []) AS conflict_types WITH region_name, geo_region_UN_M49Code, countries, conflicts, all_actors, conflict_types, [country IN countries WHERE NOT EXISTS { MATCH (country)<-[:IS_TAKING_PLACE_IN_COUNTRY]-(:Conflict) } | country.name] AS countries_not_involved, [country IN countries WHERE EXISTS { MATCH (country)<-[:IS_TAKING_PLACE_IN_COUNTRY]-(:Conflict) } | country.name] AS countries_involved, [country IN countries WHERE NOT EXISTS { MATCH (country)<-[:IS_TAKING_PLACE_IN_COUNTRY]-(:Conflict) } | { country_name: country.name, country_UN_M49Code: country.UN_M49Code }] AS countries_not_involved_details WITH region_name, geo_region_UN_M49Code, countries_not_involved, countries_involved, countries_not_involved_details, CASE WHEN SIZE(countries_not_involved) = 0 THEN "According to RULAC, all countries in " + region_name + " have been involved in at least one armed conflict." ELSE "According to RULAC, the following countries in " + region_name + " are not currently involved in an armed conflict: " + apoc.text.join(countries_not_involved, ", ") + "." END AS summary_text RETURN { summary: summary_text, countries_not_involved: countries_not_involved_details } AS RULAC_research

Input: Which 5 countries have the highest number of international armed conflicts (IACs) ?
Generated Query: WITH "International Armed Conflict (IAC)" AS target_conflict_type MATCH (c:Conflict)-[:IS_CLASSIFIED_AS_CONFLICT_TYPE]->(ct:ConflictType {type: target_conflict_type}) MATCH (c)-[:IS_PARTY_TO_CONFLICT]-(sa:StateActor) WITH sa.name AS state_actor, COUNT(DISTINCT c) AS total_conflicts, COLLECT(DISTINCT { conflict_name: c.name, conflict_classification: ct.type, conflict_overview: c.overview, applicable_ihl_law: c.applicable_law, conflict_citation: c.citation }) AS conflict_details ORDER BY total_conflicts DESC LIMIT 5 WITH COLLECT({ state_actor: state_actor, total_conflicts: total_conflicts, conflict_details: conflict_details }) AS state_actor_data, apoc.coll.flatten(COLLECT(conflict_details)) AS conflict_details RETURN { summary: "According to RULAC, the top 5 countries currently party to the most International Armed Conflicts (IACs) are, in order of involvement: " + apoc.text.join([entry IN state_actor_data | entry.state_actor + " is an official state actor engaged in " + toString(entry.total_conflicts) + " conflicts (" + apoc.text.join([conflict IN entry.conflict_details | conflict.conflict_name], ", ") + ")"], "; ") + ".", state_actor_data: state_actor_data, conflict_details: conflict_details } AS RULAC_research
Output:

2. **India**: Involved in 2 conflicts (International armed conflict between India and Pakistan, International armed conflict between India and China)
3. **Pakistan**: Involved in 2 conflicts (International Armed Conflict between Afghanistan and Pakistan, International armed conflict between India and Pakistan)
4. **Russian Federation**: Involved in 1 conflict (International armed conflict in Ukraine)
5. **Ukraine**: Involved in 1 conflict (International armed conflict in Ukraine)

target_group_name, members, COLLECT(single_state_data) AS states_conflicts WITH org, target_group_name, members, states_conflicts, apoc.coll.flatten([s IN states_conflicts | s.conflict_details]) AS conflict_details WITH org, target_group_name, members, states_conflicts, conflict_details, apoc.coll.toSet([c IN conflict_details | c.conflict_name]) AS distinct_conflict_names WITH org, target_group_name, total_members, conflict_details, distinct_conflict_names, states_conflicts, total_distinct_conflicts UNWIND states_conflicts AS state_data WITH org, target_group_name, distinct_conflict_names, total_distinct_conflicts, COLLECT(state_data) AS sorted_states WITH org, target_group_name, total_members, conflict_details, distinct_conflict_names, total_distinct_conflicts, sorted_states, "The '" + target_group_name + "' is defined as " + toString(total_members) + " members total, including: " + apoc.text.join([s IN sorted_states | s.state_name], ", ") + "." AS org_definition_text, [sc IN sorted_states WHERE sc.total_conflicts > 0 | { state_name: sc.state_name, total_conflicts: sc.total_conflicts, conflict_names: sc.conflict_names } ] AS breakdown_list WITH org, target_group_name, total_members, conflict_details, distinct_conflict_names, total_distinct_conflicts, sorted_states, breakdown_list, org_definition_text, CASE WHEN org IS NULL THEN "No organization named '" + target_group_name + "' was found in the database." Output:
### Conflicts in the Horn of Africa

According to the RULAC (Rule of Law in Armed Conflict) data, there are currently two distinct armed conflicts taking place in the Horn of Africa region, which includes the countries of Djibouti, Eritrea, Ethiopia, and Somalia. Here is a breakdown by country:

#### Ethiopia
- **Conflict Name:** Non-international armed conflicts in Ethiopia
- **Conflict Overview:** The Ethiopian central government has been engaging in a non-international armed conflict against the Oromo Liberation Army (OLA). Furthermore, Ethiopia was party to a NIAC against the Tigray People’s Liberation Front (TPLF). It has been reported that Eritrean troops were also fighting against the non-state forces.
- **Applicable IHL Law:** All parties to the conflict are bound by Article 3 common to the 1949 Geneva Conventions, which provides for the minimum standards to be respected and requires humane treatment without adverse distinction of all persons not or no longer taking active parts in hostilities. It prohibits murder, mutilation, torture, cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment, hostage taking and unfair trials. All parties are also bound by customary international humanitarian law applicable to non-international armed conflict. In addition to international humanitarian law, international human rights law continues to apply during times of armed conflict.
- **State Parties:** Ethiopia
- **Non-State Parties:** Oromo Liberation Army (OLA), Tigray People's Liberation Front (TPLF)

#### Somalia
- **Conflict Name:** Non-international armed conflict in Somalia
- **Conflict Overview:** A non-international armed conflict is taking place in Somalia, involving different international actors. The internationally recognized federal government of Somalia fights against Islamist insurgents, most prominently the armed group al-Shabaab, which has pledged allegiance to al-Qaeda. The African Union Transition Mission in Somalia (ATMIS), previously African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM), is a peacekeeping operation supporting the Somali government. Its military component is a party to the armed conflict. In addition to contributing troops to AMISOM, Kenyan and Ethiopian armed forces also operate independently in the country. The United States conducts ground and air operations against al-Shabaab and provides material support to AMISOM and Somali security forces. The non-international armed conflict involving al-Shabaab has spilled over into Kenya.
- **Applicable IHL Law:** All parties to the conflict are bound by Article 3 common to the 1949 Geneva Conventions that provides for the minimum standard to be respected and requires humane treatment without adverse distinction of all persons not or no longer taking active part in hostilities. It prohibits murder, mutilation, torture, cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment, hostage taking and unfair trials. In addition, all parties are bound by customary international humanitarian law applicable to non-international armed conflict. In addition to international humanitarian law, international human rights law continues to apply during times of armed conflict. Somalia is a party to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights as well as the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights. Under human rights law, the territorial state has an obligation to prevent and to investigate alleged violations, including by non-state actors. Non-state armed groups are increasingly considered to be bound by international human rights law if they exercise de facto control over some areas.
- **State Parties:** Somalia, Ethiopia, Kenya, United States of America
- **Non-State Parties:** Islamic State in Somalia (ISS), Al-Shabaab, African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM)
